repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Discussed in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/7189 and https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/7325 and https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6628

The forward declaration `extern int convert_current_exception_to_python();`  may be somewhat dubious. As far as I know it's needed however. Cysignals use `preliminary_late_includes_cy28` instead.

comment_data.body:

```suggestion
  as an error flag (by default, ``-1`` triggers the exception check, i.e.
  functions returning ``int`` use ``except? -1`` by default)
```

   function returning nothing (C ``void``).  Simple workarounds are to mark the
   function as ``noexcept`` if you're certain that exceptions cannot be thrown, or
   to change the return type to ``int`` and just let Cython use the return value
-  as an error flag (by default, ``-1`` triggers the exception check).
+  as an error flag (by default, ``-1`` triggers the exception check, i.e.
+  functions returning ``int`` are ``except? -1`` by default)

comment_data.body: Hmm. This section is about exception propagation. I don't think this is the best place to put this paragraph.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1059,8 +1060,13 @@ Some things to note:
   function returning nothing (C ``void``).  Simple workarounds are to mark the
   function as ``noexcept`` if you're certain that exceptions cannot be thrown, or
   to change the return type to ``int`` and just let Cython use the return value
-  as an error flag (by default, ``-1`` triggers the exception check).
+  as an error flag (by default, ``-1`` triggers the exception check, i.e.
+  functions returning ``int`` are ``except? -1`` by default)
 
+  When the return value is a C type, and the last statement is executed
+  without returning a value, the function returns ``0`` (instead of ``None``).
+  However, explicit ``return`` in the function body is not allowed, you need
+  explicit ``return 0``.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
If ``something_dangerous`` raises a C++ exception then ``raise_py_error`` will be
called during exception handling (i.e. typically, in a ``catch`` clause).
At that point, ``raise_py_error`` should retrieve the current exception object,
either by rethrowing the current exception with ``throw;`` and immediately catching it,
or via ``std::current_exception()``.  It can then set a Python exception via the ``PyErr_Set*()``
functions of the Python C-API to implement a custom error translation from C++ to Python.
See the example below. If  ``raise_py_error`` does not actually raise an exception, a
``RuntimeError`` will be raised.  This approach may also be used to manage custom
Python exceptions created using the Python C API. ::
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -457,15 +457,19 @@ that most users won't need, but for those that do a full example follows::
     cdef int raise_py_error()
     cdef int something_dangerous() except +raise_py_error
 
-If something_dangerous raises a C++ exception then raise_py_error will be
-called, which allows one to do custom C++ to Python error "translations." If
-raise_py_error does not actually raise an exception a RuntimeError will be
-raised. This approach may also be used to manage custom Python exceptions
-created using the Python C API. ::
+If ``something_dangerous`` raises a C++ exception then ``raise_py_error`` will be
+called during exception handling (i.e. typically, in a ``catch`` clause).
+From there, ``raise_py_error`` should access the exception object by,
+for example, rethrow the exception currently handled with ``throw;`` and
+immediately catch it, or use ``std::current_exception()``; then, it should set
+a Python exception, such as by ``PyErr_SetString``.
+This allows one to do custom C++ to Python error "translations".
+See the example below. If ``raise_py_error`` does not actually raise an exception a
+``RuntimeError`` will be raised. This approach may also be used to manage custom
+Python exceptions created using the Python C API. ::

comment_data.body:
I don't think the `extern` is needed, is it?
```suggestion
        int convert_current_exception_to_python();
```

The exception type pointer would need to be `static` but is generally questionable in the light of multiple interpreters and module instance state.

I'd rather implement the exception type in Cython code and pass it into the conversion function, e.g.

```cython
class MyException(Exception): pass

cdef extern from *:
    """
    static void cpp_handle_exception(PyObject *exc_type) {
        // throw, catch, PyErr_Set, etc.
    }
    """
    cdef void cpp_handle_exception(object exc_type)

cdef void translate_cpp_exception():
    cpp_handle_exception(MyException)

cdef extern from "cpplib.h":
    void raising_function() except +translate_cpp_exception
```
This paragraph talks about exception propagation from `void` functions. Mentioning a default return value seems confusing and distracting here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -982,7 +982,8 @@ If you have a
 function returning ``void`` that needs to propagate errors, you will have to
 use this form, since there isn't any error return value to test.
 Otherwise, an explicit error return value allows the C compiler to generate
-more efficient code and is thus generally preferable.
+more efficient code and is thus generally preferable, although see the note
+below regarding default return value.

comment_data.body:
I wouldn't make this change.

People were using `cpdef` with the belief that it would also expose the variable through a Python interface. `cdef public` also doesn't do that bit it sounds like it might.  So I think this is more likely to mislead than help.

I'd also consider `cdef public` to be a subset of `cdef` so it doesn't need specifically calling out.

but it does exactly that, no? (okay not 100%, but one of the things that it does is that)

```
In [2]: %%cython
   ...: cdef class A:
   ...:     cdef public int x

In [3]: a = A()

In [4]: a.x
Out[4]: 0
```

Ah you're partly right - sorry.

It only does that in classes which makes it good advice for class attributes but not for module-scoped variables. (Admittedly it's unhelpful that `public` means a different thing there, but that unfortunately historical).

Hm, the correct solution would be to use this new warning message only for class member variables (there's also `cdef readonly`, I think). But it may take me a while to figure out how to check for that.
The previous code block (above) also use that. I suppose I can change both.
it means the same either way, yes.
Reasonable. But then pretty much the only case where you may want a function that logically return nothing to return `int` is for efficient exception handling.

   function returning nothing (C ``void``).  Simple workarounds are to mark the
   function as ``noexcept`` if you're certain that exceptions cannot be thrown, or
   to change the return type to ``int`` and just let Cython use the return value
-  as an error flag (by default, ``-1`` triggers the exception check).
+  as an error flag (by default, ``-1`` triggers the exception check, i.e.
+  functions returning ``int`` are ``except? -1`` by default)
 
+  When the return value is a C type, and the last statement is executed
+  without returning a value, the function returns ``0`` (instead of ``None``).
+  However, explicit ``return`` in the function body is not allowed, you need
+  explicit ``return 0``.

comment_data.body: It might just be `env.is_c_class_scope`

I think this can be a `void` function. It doesn't need Cython error propagation since it's not meant to be called from Cython. I'd also change the name a little to make the distinction between C++ exceptions and Python exceptions clearer.
```suggestion
    cdef public void convert_current_cpp_exception_to_python() except *:
        rethrow_current_cpp_exception()  # declared as ``except+``, which translates the exception
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -545,6 +538,75 @@ listed in the table above. The code for this standard exception handler can be
 found `here
 <https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Utility/CppSupport.cpp>`__.
 
+You can reuse Cython's built-in logic with something like the following.
+Notice the ``convert_current_exception_to_python()`` function. ::
+
+    from cpython.object cimport PyObject
+
+    cdef extern from *:
+        """
+        #include <Python.h>
+        #include <stdexcept>
+        #include <ios>
+
+        void rethrow_current_exception() {
+            throw;
+        }
+
+        int convert_current_exception_to_python();

@@ -545,6 +538,75 @@ listed in the table above. The code for this standard exception handler can be
 found `here
 <https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/master/Cython/Utility/CppSupport.cpp>`__.
 
+You can reuse Cython's built-in logic with something like the following.
+Notice the ``convert_current_exception_to_python()`` function. ::
+

+
+    cdef extern from *:
+        """
+        #include <Python.h>
+        #include <stdexcept>
+        #include <ios>
+
+        void rethrow_current_exception() {
+            throw;
+        }
+
+        int convert_current_exception_to_python();
+
+        void cpp_handle_exception(PyObject *exc_type) {

 When you declare an exception value for a function, you should never explicitly
